unnormalised: The annual Diwali sale at Meena Bazaar was even crazier than expected, multiple shoppers confirmed. Initial reports suggested a slow start on Oct 20th, but things quickly picked up. By the afternoon of Oct 21st, the checkout lines snaked through the entire store.
normalised: The annual Diwali sale at Meena Bazaar was even crazier than expected, multiple shoppers confirmed. Initial reports suggested a slow start on October twentieth, but things quickly picked up. By the afternoon of October twenty first, the checkout lines snaked through the entire store.

unnormalised: Several customers reported waiting for over 2 hours just to pay for their sarees. Discounts of upto 70% off on certain items were the main draw. One shopper, Mrs. Sharma, managed to snag a Banarasi saree originally priced at Rs. 12,000 for just Rs. 3600.
normalised: Several customers reported waiting for over two hours just to pay for their sarees. Discounts of up to seventy percent off on certain items were the main draw. One shopper, Missus Sharma, managed to snag a Banarasi saree originally priced at rupee twelve thousand for just rupee three thousand six hundred.

unnormalised: Foot traffic peaked around 6 PM on Oct 22nd, causing near gridlock in the surrounding area. Police had to be called in to manage the crowds. The store reported a record-breaking day, with total sales exceeding Rs. 50 lakh. Compare this to last year's Diwali, where sales reached only Rs. 35 lakhs.
normalised: Foot traffic peaked around six P M on October twenty second, causing near gridlock in the surrounding area. Police had to be called in to manage the crowds. The store reported a record-breaking day, with total sales exceeding rupee fifty lakh. Compare this to last year's Diwali, where sales reached only rupee thirty five lakh.

unnormalised: Online sales also saw a significant boost. Meena Bazaar's website reported a 150% increase in traffic compared to a normal day. The average order value online was Rs. 3000, with many customers opting for cash on delivery. Many shoppers were buying for weddings, with heavy emphasis placed on bridal wear.
normalised: Online sales also saw a significant boost. Meena Bazaar's website reported a one hundred and fifty percent increase in traffic compared to a normal day. The average order value online was rupee three thousand, with many customers opting for cash on delivery. Many shoppers were buying for weddings, with heavy emphasis placed on bridal wear.

unnormalised: The sale is expected to continue until Oct 25th, but many popular items are already sold out. A representative for Meena Bazaar advised customers to shop early to avoid disappointment, with store opening each day at 10:00 AM.
normalised: The sale is expected to continue until October twenty fifth, but many popular items are already sold out. A representative for Meena Bazaar advised customers to shop early to avoid disappointment, with store opening each day at ten A M.
